Award.AbstractNarration:
The main problems in this proposal concern finding a general framework for Hodge theory, which can be applied to families of algebraic varieties. The proposed framework is a theory of motivic sheaves or motives with parameters. In particular, there would be a theory of motivic local systems. The latter would then lead to a notion of motivic fundamental group, which would provide a link between the topology and arithmetic of varieties. This also connects to Hodge theory in a more traditional sense, as in the study of variations of Hodge structures. A sub-project involves refinements of the Kodaira vanishing theorem using algebraic methods.

Hodge theory lies at the core of this proposal. It is the part of algebraic geometry (the study of algebraic varieties or sets of solutions of systems of algebraic equations) that interacts most closely with differential geometry, topology and to a lesser extent, mathematical physics. There are nontrivial and surprising connections with number theory as well; the theory of motives, which is also central to this proposal, arose in part to explain some of these.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to study related problems in the theory of motives, Hodge theory and the topology of algebraic varieties. The project resulted in a number of publications in  Research Journals (Advances in Mathematics, Canadian Journal of Mathematics, Compositio Mathematica, Communications of Contemp. Math, Journal de l'Ecole Polytechnique, International Math. Research Notices, and Mathematische Annalen), conference proceedings, and one Book (Algebraic Geometry over the Complex Numbers).

 

One of the main goals was to develop a theory of motives over a base, or motivic sheaves. The results were described in An abelian category of motivic sheaves, Advances in Mathematics 2013. Papers devoted to topology of (singular) algebraic varieties were 

  1. Weights on cohomology, invariants of singularities, and dual complexes, Mathematische Annalen 2013, with P. Bakhtary, and J. Wlodarczyk.
  2. Restrictions on the prime-to-p fundamental group of a smooth projective variety, Compositio 2015.
  3. On the fundamental groups of normal varieties. Commun. Contemp. Math, 2016, with A. Dimca, and R. Hain.
  4. Toward the structure of fibred fundamental groups of projective varieties, J. l'Ecole Polytechnique 2017.

Papers on Hodge theory were

  1. Hodge theory of cyclic covers branched over a union of hyperplanes. Canadian J. Math 2014.
  2. Decomposition of direct images of logarithmic differentials. Int. Math. Res. Not. 2015.

  3.  X. Chen, and S-J. Kang.
  4.  Geometric Hodge structures with prescribed Hodge numbers. Recent Advances in Hodge theory, Cambridge 2016
